docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-6 Israel Says After Meeting That It Will Pull Back Forces Israel plans to withdraw its forces from two Palestinian towns occupied after the killing of an Israeli cabinet minister on Oct. 17. Israeli officials announced the plan after a meeting with Palestinian security officials that was brokered by C.I.A. officials. The Bush administration has been urging an end to the incursions, which it has seen as a potential impediment to its efforts to build Arab support for its antiterror campaign. A6 Montenegro Talks Break Off Long-awaited talks between President Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia, left, and Milo Djukanovic, the Montenegrin president, broke off without agreement on how to run a federal Yugoslav state, and the two leaders said Montenegro must vote on independence next spring. A4

docs.lead_paragraph: Investigators looking into the deadly scaffold collapse at a Gramercy Park office building said yesterday that they were reviewing whether the accident had been caused by a makeshift hoist that was overloaded and acted like a counterweight, pulling the framework away from the building's facade and toppling it. Officials were considering several other theories about the collapse on Wednesday, which killed 5 construction workers and injured 10 others. In one scenario, officials said, one section of the scaffold was overloaded with the weight of bricks and cement that were being used to repair the southern facade of the building, at 215 Park Avenue South.

headline.main: An Overloaded Hoist Is Suspected in Scaffolding Collapse

byline.original: BY RICHARD LEZIN JONES and KEVIN FLYNN

docs.lead_paragraph: A Series Of Hiccups The New York theater had a case of the hiccups this week as several planned productions were delayed or otherwise sidetracked.
docs.abstract: On Stage and Off column; Lincoln Center Theater cancels new musical The Last Five Years and inserts Horton Foote's The Carpetbagger's Children for February; William Nicholson's The Retreat from Moscow will be produced by Susan Quint Gallin and Sandy Gallin now that Mike Nichols has withdrawn from project; Actors' Fund is flooded with aid requests from performers and industry workers in aftermath of Sept 11 terrorist attack; photo of Heather Matarazzo, 18, and Hallie Eisenberg, 9, in Roundabout Theater's The Women; Martha Plimpton joins Brian Murray in Hobson's Choice, to open at Atlantic Theater Company; SF festival of science fiction films set (S)
docs.snippet: A Series Of Hiccups      The New York theater had a case of the hiccups this week as several planned productions were delayed or otherwise sidetracked.

docs.lead_paragraph: Weyerhaeuser closed part of its saw mill in Barnesville, Ga., last week when some workers discovered a white powder on some new bandsaws they were unpacking. The men were quarantined for several hours until the saw maker assured Weyerhaeuser that the powder was just a rust preventative, not anthrax spores. Yet ''the mill kept working,'' Frank Mendizabal, a Weyerhaeuser spokesman, said. Terror-induced jitters have affected a lot of businesses since the World Trade Center and the Pentagon were attacked and anthrax-laced letters began arriving in the mail. John Mills of MyHealthBank, a company that sells health insurance online, says he spends 10 percent of his week in airport delays and fire drills. Janitors and executives alike fumble for ID's to enter their own buildings. Mail can arrive days late, delayed by gloved workers checking for suspicious envelopes. Some people now call recipients to let them know a letter is coming.

headline.main: An Economy Keeping Its Guard Up

docs.abstract: Impact of heavier security on US business in wake of Sept 11 terrorist attacks and anthrax incidents seems modest because of slowing economy itself; steps like added hours of worktime add significant costs and reduce productivity in already slowing economy, but economists say phenomenon is likely to be less of drag than they first feared; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates and Congress vowing to pass a large stimulus package, economists have said that the current downturn could end up being a short one. The economic shock from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks would make the slowdown worse, many analysts said, but the reaction would have the economy growing again by the start of next year. That outcome has suddenly begun to appear less certain.

headline.main: Economic Data Are Suggesting Slower Recovery

docs.abstract: Commerce Department reports companies' new orders for durable goods fell 8.5 percent in September, to $165.4 billion, their lowest level since 1996; National Association of Realtors says sales of existing homes dropped 11.7 percent in September; Labor Department reports jobless claims rose to 504,000 for the week, climbing above 500,000 for second time in recent weeks; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald said yesterday that it had started distributing more than $45 million in bonuses to the families of employees lost in the World Trade Center attacks. The first checks are going out this week to the families of employees whose compensation did not include sales commissions, the company said. Cantor has promised that bonuses for dead or missing workers who received commission income will be distributed at Thanksgiving, in advance of the traditional year-end bonus season on Wall Street.

headline.main: Cantor Fitzgerald Starts Paying $45 Million to Families of Lost Workers

docs.lead_paragraph: Final Agreement Reached With Bayer on Cipro Price Federal officials and Bayer executives reached final agreement on a deal that will nearly cut in half the price that Bayer charges the government for the anthrax drug Cipro. Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, sought to allay concerns about the price and availability of Cipro by emphasizing the discount and large shipments that Bayer promised. [Page B8.] Four of the nation's biggest drug companies offered specific services to help the government prepare to battle germs and diseases that could be used by terrorists. [C2.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. PHILIP T. HAYES A Protector to the End On Sept. 11, Philip T. Hayes rescued children from a day care center in 5 World Trade Center. Then, as debris fell from the sky, he ran into the south tower to redirect people out of harm's way. It had always been that way. Mr. Hayes, 67, the second oldest of 16 children, was the cornerstone of his family and its great protector. He was the patriarch.

headline.main: A Patriarch, a Woman Who Had Time for Others and a Lifelong Friend
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS

docs.abstract: Brief biographical sketches of some of victims of Sept 11 attack on World Trade Center; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For decades, the United States' economic prescription to friend and foe was almost a mantra in its consistency: leave it to the market. State intervention was out. Subsidies were a nonstarter. Government should be limited, trade should be free, and regulation should be minimal.

headline.main: European Converts to Laissez Faire See the Rush to Intervene as Heresy

docs.abstract: European Commission has been miserly, if not hostile, toward pleas for bailouts from European companies in wake of Sept 11 terrorist attacks, while US is spending billions to help airlines and is considering billions more for insurance companies; Bush administration and Congress want to jump-start American economy with new tax breaks and spending, but Europe's center-left governments have thus far avoided similar pump-priming (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Warnings and Precautions UNDER ATTACK -- The postmaster general acknowledged that he could not guarantee the safety of the mail, and President Bush warned that the nation was ''still under attack.'' Their statements reflected a growing sense that government officials had underestimated the threat posed by the anthrax contained in a handful of letters sent to Congress and news organizations. A1
